resources.string: Android Cupcake was the third release of the Android operating system and the first version to officially use a codename based on a dessert theme. Released in April 2009
Donut introduced compatibility with different screen resolutions and sizes, paving the way for Android to run on a wide range of devices, including tablets.
One of the most prominent changes in the Froyo release was USB tethering and Wi-Fi hotspot functionality.
Android 2.3 Gingerbread is the seventh version of Android, a version of the Android mobile operating system developed by Google
Android Honeycomb is the codename for the third major version of Android, designed for devices with larger screen sizes, particularly tablets
Jelly Bean marked a turning point in Android\'s evolution, emphasizing smooth performance, usability, and features that rivaled iOS.
Its primary focus was to optimize the operating system, which improves the performance of earlier devices. It takes up to 512 MB of RAM on Android devices.

One of the most prominent changes in the Lollipop release is a redesigned user interface built around a design language known as Material Design, which was made to retain a paper-like feel to the interface
